author: nmkr
title: Building on NMKR
description: How can we make the Cardano NFT ecosystem more accessible by creating tools that implement the NMKR Dev API?

f6_assessments.q0:
NFTs is probably the most popular topic in the Cardano ecosystem and the number of NFTS related projects/collections on Cardano is more than 400 according to IOG, which represents about 40% of the projects under development and counted in the IOG report.

Easing the complexity for the development of Cardano's biggest niche projects is important to expand the number of developers and make the ecosystem and tools more collaborative towards the open source path.

Although the development of solutions related to NFTs to increase Cardano adoption is important, this challenge setting has a local impact on the NFT ecosystem, this is not a critical challenge in the mission, because even if this challenge setting is not funded, proposals related to NFTS usually have space in other challenges, which has been happening in Catalyst.

This challenge setting is within the Catalyst Fund9 Challenge Setting Strategic Goals mentioned in the Proposal Assessor Guide.
f6_assessments.q1: As I mentioned in the alignment rationale, there are more than 400 NFTS related projects developed on Cardano, which represents about 40% of the entire ecosystem of projects developed on the Cardano blockchain, this demonstrates a large community of builders in this niche. Taking into account the relatively low budget and the popularity of the NFTMAKERIO (NMKR) project and its API solutions, I don't see any relevant obstacles for the community to address this challenge.
f6_assessments.q2: The definition of success and 3 key metrics proposed are relevant and appropriate for the context of this challenge setting, as they establish the number of solutions created/users, the time for development and use and projects launched successfully. I would recommend adding more qualitative metrics such as bugs or vulnerabilities found, ratio of proposals delivered/proposals not delivered after x amount of time.

f6_assessments.q0:
the alignment of this challenge falls down on the open-source metric, as this challenge would do far more to drive development into a centralized closed source NFT ecosystem (NFT-Maker pro) than it does to expand the reach, user base, or produce real-world solutions to Cardano problems.

with that said new API utility in the NFT space would indeed meet the other criteria for alignment, i.e. building real-world solutions on Cardano, and making it easier and more accessible to new people. 

as the comments on IdeaScale say, if the API were more open source this would be an easy 5-star review. however catalyst does not exist to fund development for primarily closed API ecosystems, it exists to kickstart projects on Cardano directly.
f6_assessments.q1: the Cardano ecosystem does have the capacity to meet the goals of this challenge. the budget is rather small at 100,000 ADA. but then again the goal is not one of a large impact. being only to develop API tools for a large, but niche, NFT creator backend. The budget seems reasonable even if it does not seem quite reasonable to spend Catalyst funds to develop tools for an existing project on Cardano.
f6_assessments.q2: the metrics provided to measure project success are limited. only 3 metrics are provided, and while those three are solid and easily measured, there really should be greater oversight in all aspects of catalyst. this challenge is already quite specific in its aims to aid one particular project, the verifiability is also limited in scope and presents plenty of wiggle room for projects that fall outside the goals of the catalyst fund.

f6_assessments.q0:
For the alignment of this proposal I have focused on the following Fund Goals from the Challenge Brief:
"-Prepare a group of people willing and able to contribute to the ecosystem
-Turn Cardano into an open-source project & attract more developers.
-Build real-world solutions based on the Cardano blockchain.
-Improve tooling to support human processes in Catalyst."

For these goals, the proposal is well aligned with only 1 of the 4 goals. It will help to prepare people willing and able to contribute to the ecosystem. NKKR Studio has the potential to onboad many new NFT projects and simplify the entire process. Additionally it will provide a valuable service to those looking to Launch an NFT project and evaluating what blockchain to launch it on. Services Like NMKR Studio make Cardano stand out as a great place to Launch a large NFT project. As we have seen with Martin Lawerence, this could be a great starting point for celebrities looking to Launch a project on Cardano without getting to bogged down in the technical details. This challenge will also incentivize more Cardano developers to become familiar with NMKR studio and become proficient with the platform.  

I do not think it will help with turning Cardano into an open-source project, because while NMKR is one of the most successful NFT platforms on Cardano, it is currently not open source, and is operating as a for profit, closed source, company. They have created alot of value for Cardano, however this challenge would increase their existing competitive advantage and potentially make it more difficult for other open source NFT platforms to emerge and compete for market share. In terms of building "real-world solutions" this term may be up for debate, but this challenge proposal focuses on digital assets only, and not real world (non-digital) solutions. 
This proposal is not aligned with supporting human processes in Catalyst, as it is focused on building out the NMKR NFT marketplace, and does not have anything to do with Catalyst improvements.
f6_assessments.q1: I do not see this as a challenge setting that will welcome a wide variety of solutions. While many different tools could be built for NMKR, they would all be for a single NFT platform. I would suggest the proposer re-submit to Catalyst as a series of smaller proposals to build out specific tooling, or as one proposal to incentivize new ideas. However, as mentioned above using a challenge setting to allocate funds and resources to one specific company is not well aligned with the purpose of catalyst challenge settings.  This proposal is likely to achieve results within a 6 month timeframe, as developers could work on simple tools/documentation that can be delivered quickly. It is not clear from the proposal if there is a challenge team in place to help guide participants of this challenge.
f6_assessments.q2:
The metrics for measuring success outcomes are included in the proposal as:
-Tools/Projects successfully released
-Time from funding to market
-Amount of users for these projects/tools
These metrics are easy to verify and audit by the catalyst community, except for the amount of users for these projects/tools, it is not clear if NMKR is going to be tracking and reporting these metrics to Catalyst or not. I would suggest the proposer to include a plan for verifying the success of this challenge, and explain how the challenge proposal metrics will be tracked and reported to Catalyst community members.

f6_assessments.q0: This challenge proposal has the goal of creating space for proposals that will integrate the NMKR Studio API, a community-built set of tools that facilitates the creation and usage of NFTs by regular developers, not necessarily blockchain developers. This API has already been developed by the NFT-MAKER project, and the goal is to create tool that will focus on integrations, standalone tools, marketplaces, launchpads and other applications. This challenge is good, but it required the use of a specific tool built by a team and a challenge in Catalyst ideally should not have this kind of requirement. Although, some of the goals of Cardano’s mission for Fund 10 might be addressed by this challenge, such as attracting more developers and building real-world solutions using CNFTs. Since the budget requested for this challenge is 100k ADA, which is relatively low, I believe the issue of having a project-specific challenge is lower, but it would be better to have something like this as a Catalyst Natives challenge. Overall, I believe the alignment of this proposal is ok.
f6_assessments.q1: The main characteristic of this proposal that increases its feasibility, in my opinion, is the requested budget of 100k ADA. Using current ADA value, the budget for the proposal would be around $50k, and I believe that Catalyst already has a community that is able to come up with good proposals to be submitted in this challenge and use its budget in a positive way. Also, developers that are already using the NMKR Studio API but are currently not in Catalyst will have this change to enter the ecosystem by submitting proposals in this challenge. Besides that, there are already many developers in Catalyst that don’t know about the tool yet and might end up getting learning about it and getting interested in submitting their projects there. Because of all this points, I believe this challenge proposal’s feasibility is very high.
f6_assessments.q2: The KPIs included in the proposals to track the challenge’s success are good and they are all measurable. It’s possible to track the number of tools/projects successfully released, the time from funding to market and their number of users. These KPIs would already be enough, but I could suggest some more. For example, KPIs related to the applications suggested: integrations, standalone tools, marketplaces and launchpads. Also, KPIs related to Cardano’s mission: new developers building on Cardano and real-world applications that are using the tools developed through this challenge. Considering all this points, I believe this challenge success can be verified by the community and the challenge team in the future, in case it gets voted in.

f6_assessments.q0: NFTs are definitely one of the torchbearers of this outgoing bull market (or recently ended bull market), both in Cardano and every other L1 that has experienced the phenomenon. In fact, Charles himself stated that the phenomenon of NFTs was something he was not expecting. Having said that, there is no doubt that NMKR is one of the most prominent players in the NFT market in Cardano. Which is why said team comes up with this challenging proposal, which seeks to empower creators through the creation of tools that can integrate with one of their best products, the NMKR Studio API. While I can find alignment with Cardano's mission, I would have liked the team to touch on the open features of these proposals.
f6_assessments.q1: While this challenge is particularly technical, I don't think it will be a problem for the community in terms of responsiveness and engagement. In the past, the topic associated with NFT has been very successful. A quick search of past data revealed more than 200 proposals relating to this topic. The amount requested represents 0.07% of the total budget available for the next fund, so I believe that the amount requested is appropriate.
f6_assessments.q2: Success criteria are described in a simple manner, but are appropriate for the challenge's objectives. On the other hand, only 3 measurement metrics are presented. The first two are focused on measuring the performance of the challenge itself, the last one is more focused on serving as a guide for potential proposers in case this challenge is selected. Also included in the challenge setting section is a question that questions the proposers and possible ways in which it can be answered, this serves as a guide to possible expected directions within this challenge.

f6_assessments.q0: This challenge setting is in partial alignment with the strategic goals of fund 9 as it checks the boxes of encouraging open source development, brings real world solutions, improves tools and enables more folks to contribute. The NFT market still grows at an exponential rate despite a significant correction in the overall crypto market cap. NFT Maker Pro has certainly contributed to this growth and this challenge may be well placed to make significant impact. In the comment section there is a discussion that implies NFT Maker Pro should make its platform open sourced if public funds are requested.
f6_assessments.q1: Feasibility of this challenge setting is somewhat difficult to assess as there is very little community input discussing a need for this API to have greater integration into future Cardano development. The team behind NFT Maker Pro certainly delivered on that product, so that bodes well for future integrations. The remaining question that needs to be answered is what is demand from open source developers for a proprietary API?
f6_assessments.q2: Accountability for a challenge setting is a bit trickier than for projects which depend on measurable KPIs in order to determine progress towards completion. This challenge setting does provide sufficient metrics by which success of the challenge can be measured. An audit of the number of tools and projects released using this API, and the number of users that interact with these items provides sufficient accountability for this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
Based on the information provided in this challenge setting proposal, I think that it only addresses three of the four strategic goals for fund 9. The challenge setting addresses the first strategic goal (prepare a group of people to make contributions to the ecosystem) because it encourages people to make more use cases for the NMKR studio API in order to enhance the Cardano NFT ecosystem. All of the people who address this challenge and are funded will end up contributing to the Cardano ecosystem. The proposers of this challenge setting provided some basic guidance on what is expected of future proposers, such as integrations, standalone tools, marketplaces, and launchpads. If I were someone looking to address this challenge, I would feel mostly prepared.

The challenge setting partially addresses the second strategic goal (build an open-source ecosystem and attract developers) because it will definitely be able to bring in new developers. Building new integrations with the NMKR API, new marketplaces, and new launchpads will all require people with developer skill sets. As a result, I foresee new devs coming into the ecosystem trying to work on NFTs and making more of them on the Cardano blockchain. However, the proposers did not mention anything about future proposers making their work open-source. Since blockchain is all about open-source software, I would encourage the proposers of this challenge setting to build in a statement encouraging future proposers to have a plan to make their software open-source when possible. That way, this challenge setting would better address the second strategic goal. 

The challenge setting addresses the third strategic goal (build real-world solutions on the Cardano blockchain) because NFTs themselves can have real uses. For example, NFTs can be used for digitizing famous art, real estate, music rights, etc. Making it easier to mint NFTs would open the door to more of these potential real-world cases on the Cardano blockchain. More integrations of the NMKR API would allow regular developers to also contribute to the NFT ecosystem, boosting NFT growth on Cardano. 

The challenge setting does not address the fourth strategic goal (improve tooling to support Catalyst processes) because there was no mention of how this challenge could do so. I understand that it might be difficult to tie in a project, such as this one into the fourth strategic goal. One connection I see that could potentially have use is the implementation of NFTs that can serve as digital identities for Catalyst community members. However, this use case would only be accessible after proposals from this challenge setting make the NMKR API more readily usable by normal developers. Just a suggestion that would have made this challenge setting fully address this strategic goal.

Since the challenge setting did not fully address all four strategic goals, I can only give it a score of 4 for alignment. (score given: 4)
f6_assessments.q1:
Based on the information provided in the proposal and my understanding of Cardano, I think there is potential for the Cardano community to address this challenge. I am not too familiar with all of the NFT developers on Cardano. However, I think there would be interest from developers who want to make these technologies more accessible to a wider audience. People would always appreciate easier ways to create NFTs, so there is demand from the community. This challenge is relatively small, so it does not require a huge group backing it in order to be successful – even a handful of developers could make it happen.

As for the budget (100,000 ADA), I think that it is reasonable for this challenge setting. It is important that there are some funds delegated towards building the NFT space on Cardano. The budget can fund a good number of proposals. At the same time, it is a smaller challenge setting with a smaller scope, so the budget accurately reflects that. Overall, I think that there are no problems with feasibility, so I can give this challenge a score of 5 for feasibility. (score given: 5)
f6_assessments.q2:
Based on the information provided in the proposal, I think that the metrics of success are defined for the focus area (increasing the number of use-cases for the NMKR studio API). The proposers of this challenge setting listed three key metrics of success: tools/projects successfully released, time from funding to market, and amount of users for these tools. While I think that these metrics are good ideas because they show certain aspects of success, the proposers could have been a bit more specific about metrics on the NFTs (as they are the most important outcome of this challenge setting). Maybe a metric like “number of NFTs minted using tools developed from this challenge setting” would have been good because it shows how the challenge setting resulted in more NFTs in the Cardano ecosystem. Adding some metrics like these would also make the outcomes for future proposals clearer – people would understand what kinds of things they can use to measure success for their API applications. The metrics given can encourage healthy competition between proposals because future proposers will try and optimize the efficiency in which people can mint NFTs using their platforms. 

Since this challenge setting proposal had some good metrics of success for the focus area but could have used a couple more in other areas, I can give this challenge setting a score of 4 for verifiability. (score given: 4)

importance: We should incentivize builders to create tools that advance the Cardano NFT space without being reliant on the tool to become cash-positive.
success: Multiple NFT tools implementing the NMKR Dev API have been released.
